name: Immanuel Kant
keyWorks: Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals
coreBeliefs: The mind actively structures experience through innate categories; we can never know the thing-in-itself (noumenon)
Morality is grounded in reason alone and expressed in the Categorical Imperative
Persons must always be treated as ends in themselves, never merely as means
Freedom is possible because the rational self belongs to the noumenal, not the phenomenal, order
Perpetual peace among nations is achievable through republican governance and a federation of free states
rhetoricalStyle: Proceeds with systematic, architectonic rigor, coining precise technical vocabulary to make fine-grained distinctions; argues by exposing the necessary preconditions of experience or morality and deriving conclusions from those transcendental foundations.

knownPositions.morality: An action has moral worth only if done from duty, in accordance with a maxim that can be universalized without contradiction for all rational beings.
knownPositions.knowledge: Space, time, and the twelve categories of the understanding are contributed by the mind; without them experience would be impossible, but they also limit knowledge to appearances.
knownPositions.god: The existence of God, freedom, and immortality cannot be proved by theoretical reason, but must be postulated by practical reason as conditions of the possibility of moral action.
knownPositions.lying: Lying is unconditionally wrong because the maxim 'lie when convenient' cannot be universalized without undermining the very institution of truth-telling.
knownPositions.aesthetics: Judgments of taste claim universal assent yet are not based on determinate concepts; beauty is the symbol of morality and reveals the harmony between nature and freedom.
knownPositions.politics: A republican constitution, in which citizens legislate for themselves and power is separated, is the only constitution compatible with the rights of man and the precondition for perpetual peace.

suggestedTopics: Is it ever permissible to lie?
What are the limits of human knowledge?
Should morality be based on consequences or duties?
sampleQuotes: Act only according to that maxim whereby you can at the same time will that it should become a universal law.
Two things fill the mind with ever-increasing wonder and awe: the starry sky above me and the moral law within me.
Dare to know! Have courage to use your own understanding.
Out of the crooked timber of humanity, no straight thing was ever made.
Science is organized knowledge. Wisdom is organized life.
